rounds.response:
I flop the bottom pair (my 4 paired with the 4♣), behind any higher pair/over-pair/kicker, but a single opponent on a paired board (Q-Q-Q) gives me 16.67 % of the pot already and a made hand. Yet any Queen now beats me, and my kicker is a low 5, so marginal showdown strength at best. I’m out of position; therefore, protecting equity is less important than controlling pot-size.  

Strategy: Fold rather than feed a likely better made hand.  

[Fold]

rounds.response: Two hands in a row I’ve check-folded the flop when the opponent showed post-flop aggression, and now he’s ordered his third free flop into my pre-flop flat call of 10 chips. I elected just to call with 5♥ 4♠ instead of re-raising, but once the board comes Q♥ Q♦ 4♣ I’ve paired my bottom card (4) with a potential back-door straight between my 5 and 4, but the paired board heavily reduces the effectiveness of hitting a gut-shot straight (7→6 for the deuce wheel or 8→9→J for the wheel).I don’t expect makes any profit continuing here with my modest 4 kicker in a multi-way pot, and so I fold immediately to his continuation bet to avoid later committing chips on a thin value line. Time to move on to the next round chalking up that 30-chip pot as a neutral-profit citing fold-rate to better avoid future post-flop risk stacks.

Look at the flop.

With 7♣ 7♦ you have:

- A pocket pair of 7s  
- Made hand: 7♣ 7♦ → 7♠ 7♦ 7♥ 7♠ 7♦ 7♣ 7♠ 7♦ 7♠ 7♦ 7♣ 7♥ 7♠ 7♦ 7♣ 7♠ 7♦ 7♥ 7♠ 7♦ 7♣ → **a pair of sevens**

- The board is two jacks (J♥ J♣) + 4♥ – no draws, no over-cards to your pair aside from JJ. You lose to any Jx hand but beat one-pair lower pairs, ace-high combos, etc.  
- The pot is small (60) and Villain’s 20 bet is sizing for information.  
- With 870 chips left, calling 20 to see the turn also keeps a big stack behind you and lets you re-evaluate if the turn blanks.

Decision for this spot: **call** the 20 chips and maneuver on later streets.

[Call]
